title: Malva alcea
text:
Malva alcea (greater musk-mallow, cut-leaved mallow, vervain mallow or hollyhock mallow) is a plant in the <a href="Malvaceae">mallow family</a> native to southwestern, central and eastern <a href="Europe">Europe</a> and southwestern <a href="Asia">Asia</a>, from <a href="Spain">Spain</a> north to southern <a href="Sweden">Sweden</a> and east to <a href="Russia">Russia</a> and <a href="Turkey">Turkey</a>.
Description.
It is a <a href="herbaceous">herbaceous</a> <a href="perennial%20plant">perennial plant</a> growing to 50–125 cm tall, with stems covered in stellate hairs, meaning they branch at the free end into several strands. The <a href="leaf">leaves</a> are 2–8 cm long and 2–8 cm broad, palmately lobed with five to seven blunt lobes; basal leaves on the lower stem are very shallowly lobed, those higher on the stems are deeply divided, with digitate finger-like lobes. The <a href="flower">flower</a>s appear singly near the apex of <a href="corymb">corymb</a>ose <a href="raceme">raceme</a>s growing from the leaf axils in summer to early fall. They are 3.5–6 cm diameter, with five <a href="sepal">sepal</a>s and five bright pink <a href="petal">petal</a>s, and have no scent. The bracteoles that make up the epicalyx are ovate and wide at the base where they are fused with the <a href="sepal">calyx</a>. The <a href="fruit">fruit</a> is a hairless disc-shaped <a href="schizocarp">schizocarp</a> 4–8 mm diameter, containing several <a href="seed">seed</a>s, the seeds individually enclosed in a glabrous or hairy <a href="mericarp">mericarp</a>. It has a <a href="chromosome">chromosome</a> count of 2n=84.
Ecology.
It is most common in drier soils in thickets, along paths and in waste places. <a href="Natural%20hybrid">Natural hybrid</a>s with the closely related "<a href="Malva%20moschata">Malva moschata</a>" are occasionally found. In central Europe it grows at altitudes of up to 2,000 m.
Cultivation and uses.
It has been widely grown outside of its native range as an <a href="ornamental%20plant">ornamental plant</a>. Several <a href="cultivar">cultivar</a>s exist such as 'Fastigata', an upright form, and 'Alba', a white flowered form. In some areas, such as the northeastern <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, the plant has escaped from cultivation and become <a href="naturalisation%20%28biology%29">naturalised</a>. It is very similar to, and often confused with "Malva moschata".
